Message.Title: Google Earnings Miss - Not Earnings Beat
Message.Msg: Were it not for the Motorola acquisition costs that showed favorable tax rate, Google would have missed this quarter, instead of beating it. Not sure if the analysts already included this in their calculation. If they did not include this, they could consider this an earnings miss and not an earnings beat.

Message.Title: cyber security article
Message.Msg: Congress is still working on a bill, or plan to tighten things up,, not sure what or when, but nice to see it get attention. Late Thursday, the Obama administration reiterated that cybersecurity is a top priority and said it would work with both parties to build on the House legislation and get a bill through the Senate. "While CISPA has been improved in each of the administration's priority areas since its introduction this year, the bill does not yet adequately address our fundamental concerns," said Laura Lucas, a spokeswoman for the White House's National Security Council. "We are hopeful that continued bipartisan, bicameral collaboration to incorporate our core priorities will produce cybersecurity legislation that addresses these critical issues and that the president can sign into law." Industry groups that supported the measure welcomed the House's action. Backers included the wireless group CTIA, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and TechNet, which represents big technology companies such as Google Inc, Apple Inc, Yahoo! Inc and Cisco Systems Inc.

Message.Title: Don't give up Chromebook. Some in-depth consumer analysis is required indeed.
Message.Msg: We don't expect Chromebook to replace WIndows anytime soon from business side. In cloud computing age, there is no computing device so far in the market can satisfy all the needs. iPad sucks in knowing what a user has in the "book" locally while Windows book sucks resource and memory on non-user related stuff, i.e. MSFT always enjoys itself other than users' experience. How to define a local book and its OS becomes vital to cloud computing and storage. No one knows at this point.

Topic.Title: Where is the IRS/FED/SEC on that 8% tax !!!!!!!
4 main negative factors in recent earning.

Message.Msg: all i read is, "I took da bizness in da college, and dont know abutz longsterms potenshells" First of all, missing anything related to analyst estimates means nothing. It doesn't mean up or down, left or right, or diagonally. Especially when the stock randomly drops 20 points on the day of earnings. That just means it wasn't sitting in the right place to begin with. Cost per click, in EVERY study I've read, is supposed to go up. You're probably comparing it to a holiday quarter where advertising budgets are through the roof.... Motorola is a drain....right now. No one is arguing that. However, its potential far outweighs this current "restructuring" period its going through. Look at the popularity of googles nexus line based solely on the fact that its PURE ANDROID. People love it, and will gobble up googles hardware for potential hundreds of billions of net worth. Tax paid..the QE is on going. Less tax, means more RandD, and more expansion. Where the problem?

Message.Title: CCUR to be Next Week's Best Performer
Message.Msg: Next week's #1 performer could be CCUR, probably the most undervalued NASDAQ stock with the biggest upside potential in the market. Only $6.60 with 8.72mm shares outstanding and a market cap of $57.55mm. It has $24.6mm in cash and no debt. Enterprise value is $33mm or only 0.52X its trailing revenues of $63mm. 2Q 2013 EPS was up 100% from 1Q 2013 and =1Q 2013 EPS was up 100% from 4Q 2012. Their 3Q 2013 EPS is due out very soon! If you watch video on demand using your cable TV service and subscribe to Cox, Time Warner Cable, Charter, or Bright House, CCUR provides your VOD services. CCUR just signed another major unnamed top 5 North American pay-TV company! CCUR last month signed a major multi-screen TV deal to provide mobile video delivery with Virgin Media (VMED) the #1 pay-TV company in the UK. CCUR's EPS is likely to continue skyrocketing!

Message.Title: iPhone monthly ad share grew 12%.
Message.Msg: The iPhone monthly ad share grew 12% in the first quarter of this year and now accounts for more than 50% of mobile ad spending, according to the report released Thursday by MoPub, a mobile ad exchange that allows app publishers and advertisers to engage in bidding for advertisements. As a result, the cost-per-thousand views is 40% higher on iOS than Google’s Android.

Topic.Title: 4 main negative factors in recent earning.

Message.Msg: Apple, in my personal opinion, has no growth ahead of its self. It pigeonholed itself into a market that was eventually going to be saturated. They have nothing in the pipeline that will help them out of the mess they are in. They thought their patents would save them, but thats not the case. Apple is dead. The amount of cash they have on hand will ensure its a lengthy drawn out death, but its comparable to someone having a fatal disease... Google on the other hand has made incredibly good strategic decisions for cementing their future prospects. I named a few already. Advertising is always going to be a big business, and google isn't waiting for advertisers, they are creating new advertising marketplaces. Do you realize how powerful that is? Cost per click, again, is down compared to what? The holiday season? In general, its supposed to go up, what happens in one quarter is pointless. Google is continously making strides in mobile to ensure relevant content. Mobile cpc is going to jump, especially since penetration is continue to rise. Again, whether they missed their numbers or not..who cares. They made a ton of money, and did so while spending a ton, and setting up many amazing long term investments. Google wins. everything.

Topic.Title: 4 main negative factors in recent earning.

Message.Msg: Personally, Google is in a much stronger position as a social media 'tool' than facebook. Facebook relies far too heavily on its massive amount of traffic and doesn't have the infrastructure in place to survive once that traffic dries up (It already is!) Google on the otherhand, built Google+ as a tool to supplement all its other offerings. It automatically loads all my pictures into it, I pick and choose what I want to put out there. Either way, its stored for me...automatically. Gmail, hangouts, youtube, google play, etc. They are learning far more than facebook could by creating your digital persona through services that YOU REQUIRE in day to day activities. Apple is not a competitor to google anymore. They are wiped out. MS is the next target with Google Chromebooks and Google Drive. Twitter and Pandora? Not following that one. but even so, they don't pose a threat. I agree no growth goes on forever. Unless you plan for it. Google is the one company that I would ever acknowledge as being adaptable. They haven't trapped themselves in any one area. They are always on the cutting edge and constantly adapting their core principals. Its not just 'advertising' thats far too simple.

Topic.Title: iPhone monthly ad share grew 12%.

Message.Msg: Your facts are correct about the ad share, but management is inept when it comes to managing the stock price. They openly don't care the share price and thus give lots of cover to short sellers especially during times of no new product announcements like now... Very, very poorly done, Mr. Tim Cook!
